name: Rehuel Lobatto
content:
Rehuel Lobatto (June 6, 1797 – February 9, 1866) was a Dutch mathematician. Lobatto was born in Amsterdam to a Portuguese Jewish family. As a schoolboy Lobatto already displayed remarkable talent for mathematics.[1]  He studied mathematics under Adolphe Quetelet coediting "Correspondance Mathématique et Physique." Working for the Dutch government he became secretary of a statistical commission in 1831.[2]
In 1836 he became member of the Royal Institute, predecessor of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences.[3] In 1842 he became a teacher at the Polytechnical School of Delft.
 The Gauss-Lobatto quadrature method is named after him.
 
 This article about a Dutch scientist is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. This article about a European mathematician is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. This article about a statistician is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.
tags: Members of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences
raw:
Dutch mathematician
 Rehuel Lobatto
 Plaque in Delft
Rehuel Lobatto (June 6, 1797 – February 9, 1866) was a Dutch mathematician. Lobatto was born in Amsterdam to a Portuguese Jewish family. As a schoolboy Lobatto already displayed remarkable talent for mathematics.[1]  He studied mathematics under Adolphe Quetelet coediting "Correspondance Mathématique et Physique." Working for the Dutch government he became secretary of a statistical commission in 1831.[2]
In 1836 he became member of the Royal Institute, predecessor of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences.[3] In 1842 he became a teacher at the Polytechnical School of Delft.
The Gauss-Lobatto quadrature method is named after him.

^ Entry in jewishencyclopedia

^
